Threads.Subject: Look out for our new device launching 18th Jan !
Threads.Body:
Look out for our newest, mid-range Bluetooth LE SoC (and upcoming module). Launching, 18th Jan the DA14592 offers lowest power consumption and smallest solution footprint in its class. With multi-core processing (Cortex®-M33 , Cortex-M0+), 15-bit ADC, plenty of GPIOs and optimized trade between on-chip memory (RAM/ROM/Flash) and SoC die size for cost, it's very well suited to a broad range of applications...maybe include yours?

Update ;; here it is  !

DA14592 - SmartBond  Multi-Core Bluetooth® LE 5.2 SoC with Embedded Flash | Renesas

Threads.Subject: Bad connectivity issues with a few DA14531MOD
Threads.Body:
We use DA14531 modules in our production units. These modules are pre-programmed and tested before adding them to the main board. 

We have noticed that a few production units suffer from bad connectivity. At closer ranges (less than 2 metres), the RSSI value drops to about -85dBm, which further drops to about -100dBm as the receiver is moved further. Some have a reduced range of about 4 to 6m. A few disconnects within a couple of metres range and then does not advertise again. The user can see the advertisement name again once the unit is rebooted.

These modules were all tested while running at the highest power level (AT+PWRLVL=12). 

Is there a way to test and verify what is causing the bad connectivity (Any hardware failure, antenna issues or insufficient power supply consumption). If not, would it be possible to test any particular value and reject the module before adding them to the production boards. Most of the time, RSSI does not provide much significant data at closer distances (before adding them to the board) during production stages.

P.S. The Codeless version has been upgraded from SDK6.380.12.6 to SDK6.380.16.55, which did not solve the issue.

Kind Regards,

Arun

Threads.Subject: Da14531 PEAK power ISSUE IN ADVERTISEMENT TIME
Threads.Body:
Hi team ,

     WITH DA14531 custom device. for one sec advertisement.

  •  Peak power takes upto 49 milliamps.
  •  Average power takes 99 micro amps
  •  Sleep mode 1.5 micro amps

Sleep mode working as expected .but every time during advertisement the peak current goes to 50 milli amps.  how to reduce power because for one sec advertisement takes nearly 99 micro amps?have

used spi flash power down  spi_flash_power_down(); once the bytes reading is completed from the flash.

Awaiting for reply

Thanks,

Sowmiya

Threads.Subject: DA14531 DMA Use Questions
Threads.Body:
Hello,

I'm hoping to use the DA14531 to transfer sensor data (2-3 sensors via SPI, and possibly also from the ADC) at around 40-60kilobits/s and was running into problems when using the system processor for timing, sampling, and sending data. I realize that this application will likely require configuration of the DMA to handle the data movement and wanted to ask for some help on this topic.

I believe the problems I was encountering was due to the sampling timing interfering with the BLE transmission process, causing crashes.

  1. Is it practical to use the system processor for timing as well as BLE transfer? Or should I try to offload the sampling timing (running a timer to trigger each sample) to an external component to avoid BLE transfer collisions?
  2. Is this goal practical with the DA14531 & DMA?
    1. My initial thought would be to use the DMA to fill a transmission buffer, and once full, move the DMA to a different memory location, transmit the first buffer, and repeat the process for the second.
    2. Is this data rate practical while handling input BLE notifications?
    3. Can the SPI & DMA system handle multiple sensor inputs at once? (Say, two simultaneous inputs of 20 bit messages)
  3. What would the best source of information be to utilize the DMA in this way? I have seen a few examples of DMA use but I can't seem to find one combining DMA and BLE transfers.
  4. I saw the new DA14592 device and see that the dual-core design might make it easier to handle all these goals at once. Would this be a better solution for my project?

Thank you in advance for the help and advice.

Threads.Subject: DA14531 Devkit pro recovery from flashed faulty FW
Threads.Body:
Hi,

SDK: 6.0.20.1338
Toolbox version: 5.0.22.4084
Device: DA14531MOD-00DEVKT-P with daughterboard
OS: Ubuntu 20.04 in virtual machine

I'm using DA14531MOD devkit pro with daughterboard, with an apparent faulty FW I flashed using Toolbox "Flash Code" option (OPT has not been touched) that I cannot connect to anymore. I have edited the flashed FW.

From other threads I have gathered that I should erase and flash using 1-wire uart, but I cannot find the instructions for it when using the daughterboard.

What I have tried is setting the jumpers according to figure 20 in DA14531 SMARTBOND TINY MODULE Development Kit Hardware User Manual, and attempting to flash using SmartSnippets Toolbox as well as Flash Programmer (v. 1.0.12.4140). In Toolbox in Board Setup I have set UART Communication to P0_5, P0_5, 115200 Bd, and SPI Flash pin configuration to: CLK: P0_4, CS: P0_1, MISO: P0_3,  MOSI: P0_0.

Attempting to Connect from Flash Code tab or clicking Download Code Image from RAM tab only prints "Could not measure total IR len. TDO is constant high". Flash Programmer shows the device as "Undetected".

Does anyone have any idea what I'm doing wrong?

Threads.Subject: App easy timer stop working until 10 minutes later
Threads.Body:
Hello,

Our project is using DA14585 chip and SDK version is 6.0.20, but I think previous SDK versions should also have the issue. The scenario is like the following:

1. There is a 1 second timeout easy timer running periodically, by staring itself in its timeout callback.

2. There is a GPIO wakeup interrupt. The interrupt handler first checks and cancels the previous 10ms timeout and 3s timeout timers if they still exist, and then starts a new 10ms timeout timer.

3. In the 10ms timeout timer callback, if the GPIO level is high, there are 2 timers being created: one is 200ms timeout, the other is 3s timeout. For the 200ms timeout timer, if the high-level GPIO interrupt happens before its timeout, it will be cancelled and created again.

4. If making GPIO interrupt happens very frequently, the 1s timeout timer callback won't be called until 10 minutes later.

5. Analyzing log in easy timer APIs, there isn't anything wrong in creating and cancelling timers.

Thanks,

Jerry

2. There is a GPIO wakeup interrupt. The interrupt handler first checks and cancels the previous 10ms timeout and 3s timeout timers if they still exist, and then starts a new 10ms timeout timer.

3. In the 10ms timeout timer callback, if the GPIO level is high, there are 2 timers being created: one is 200ms timeout, the other is 3s timeout. For the 200ms timeout timer, if the high-level GPIO interrupt happens before its timeout, it will be cancelled and created again.

4. If making GPIO interrupt happens very frequently, the 1s timeout timer callback won't be called until 10 minutes later.

5. Analyzing log in easy timer APIs, there isn't anything wrong in creating and cancelling timers.

Thanks,

Jerry

Threads.Subject: Sending unsigned char data to remote peer (BLE) using ke_msg_send()
Threads.Body:
I am trying to send unsigned char data, which would include null characters as data and not as end of data, to remote peer (BLE) using the following modified function:

void send_to_remote_Hex(uint8_t* str_to_send, uint8_t count)
{
    extern bool is_connected(void);
    if (is_connected())
    {

        // Write response string to Bluetooth peer
#if !defined(__DA14531_01__)
        if (codeless_env.bt_role == GAP_ROLE_CENTRAL)
        {
 

            // Codeless device is central/client
            struct custs1_env_tag *prf_env=PRF_ENV_GET(CUSTS1, custs1);
            user_prf_gatt_write(codeless_env.hdl_inbound_val, (uint8_t *)str_to_send, count,  GATTC_WRITE, 0);
            
        } 
        else
#endif        
        {
#if !defined(OUTBOUND_CHAR_QUEUE)
             // Codeless device is peripheral/server
            struct custs1_val_set_req* req
                = KE_MSG_ALLOC_DYN(CUSTS1_VAL_SET_REQ, prf_get_task_from_id(TASK_ID_CUSTS1),
                                   TASK_APP, custs1_val_set_req, count);
            req->conidx = app_env->conhdl;
            req->handle = CUST1_IDX_OUTBOUND_VAL;

            req->length = count;
            memcpy(req->value, str_to_send, count);
            ke_msg_send(req);
#else
        //    outbound_char_enqueue_hex(str_to_send, count);
            struct custs1_value_req_rsp *rsp = KE_MSG_ALLOC_DYN(CUSTS1_VALUE_REQ_RSP,
                                                        prf_get_task_from_id(TASK_ID_CUSTS1),
                                                        TASK_APP,
                                                        custs1_value_req_rsp,
                                                        count);            
            // Provide the connection index.
            rsp->conidx = app_env->conhdl;
            // Provide the attribute index.
            //rsp->att_idx = app_env;
            // Set current length to the string length plus one more byte
            rsp->length  = count;
            // Provide the ATT error code.
            rsp->status  = ATT_ERR_NO_ERROR;
            // Copy value 
            memcpy(rsp->value, str_to_send, count);
            // Explicitly add zero termination to the string since this is expected 
            // in the air by the codeless central.The SmartConsole application does not need it.
            rsp->value[rsp->length-1]=0;
            // Send message
            ke_msg_send(rsp); 
#endif            
#if !defined(__DA14531_01__)
            if (codeless_env.bt_role != GAP_ROLE_CENTRAL) 
#endif
            {
                // Notify Bluetooth peer
                
                struct custs1_val_ntf_ind_req* req2
                        = KE_MSG_ALLOC_DYN(CUSTS1_VAL_NTF_REQ, prf_get_task_from_id(TASK_ID_CUSTS1),
                                       TASK_APP, custs1_val_ntf_ind_req, 1);
                req2->notification = true;
                req2->conidx = app_env->conhdl;
                req2->handle = CUST1_IDX_FLOW_CONTROL_VAL;
                req2->length = 1;
                req2->value[0] = 0x01;
                ke_msg_send(req2);
                
                //user_send_remote_notification(CUST1_IDX_FLOW_CONTROL_VAL, 0x01, 0, 1);
            }
 
        }

    } else {
#ifdef AT_CONSOLE_PRINT_ERROR_MESSAGES			
        at_console_error_report(AT_CONSOLE_ERROR_7); // Tried to send to peer but no connection
        send_to_local(OK_TERMINATION_STRING);
#endif			
    }
}

Since void outbound_char_enqueue(const char* string_ptr) uses char* and string functions, which sees null as end of data, I am trying to send it using another way. Could you please help me send an array of data to remote BLE that would include null values.

P.S. The SDK used is Codeless SDK6.380.16.55. I am still using void send_to_remote(char* str_to_send) for sending string data, but using send_to_remote_hex() for sending data that includes null values.

Content.HtmlName: Sending unsigned char data to remote peer (BLE) using ke_msg_send()
Content.HtmlDescription:
I am trying to send unsigned char data, which would include null characters as data and not as end of data, to remote peer (BLE) using the following modified function:

void send_to_remote_Hex(uint8_t* str_to_send, uint8_t count)
{
    extern bool is_connected(void);
    if (is_connected())
    {

        // Write response string to Bluetooth peer
#if !defined(__DA14531_01__)
        if (codeless_env.bt_role == GAP_ROLE_CENTRAL)
        {
 

            // Codeless device is central/client
            struct custs1_env_tag *prf_env=PRF_ENV_GET(CUSTS1, custs1);
            user_prf_gatt_write(codeless_env.hdl_inbound_val, (uint8_t *)str_to_send, count,  GATTC_WRITE, 0);
            
        } 
        else
#endif        
        {
#if !defined(OUTBOUND_CHAR_QUEUE)
             // Codeless device is peripheral/server
            struct custs1_val_set_req* req
                = KE_MSG_ALLOC_DYN(CUSTS1_VAL_SET_REQ, prf_get_task_from_id(TASK_ID_CUSTS1),
                                   TASK_APP, custs1_val_set_req, count);
            req->conidx = app_env->conhdl;
            req->handle = CUST1_IDX_OUTBOUND_VAL;

            req->length = count;
            memcpy(req->value, str_to_send, count);
            ke_msg_send(req);
#else
        //    outbound_char_enqueue_hex(str_to_send, count);
            struct custs1_value_req_rsp *rsp = KE_MSG_ALLOC_DYN(CUSTS1_VALUE_REQ_RSP,
                                                        prf_get_task_from_id(TASK_ID_CUSTS1),
                                                        TASK_APP,
                                                        custs1_value_req_rsp,
                                                        count);            
            // Provide the connection index.
            rsp->conidx = app_env->conhdl;
            // Provide the attribute index.
            //rsp->att_idx = app_env;
            // Set current length to the string length plus one more byte
            rsp->length  = count;
            // Provide the ATT error code.
            rsp->status  = ATT_ERR_NO_ERROR;
            // Copy value 
            memcpy(rsp->value, str_to_send, count);
            // Explicitly add zero termination to the string since this is expected 
            // in the air by the codeless central.The SmartConsole application does not need it.
            rsp->value[rsp->length-1]=0;
            // Send message
            ke_msg_send(rsp); 
#endif            
#if !defined(__DA14531_01__)
            if (codeless_env.bt_role != GAP_ROLE_CENTRAL) 
#endif
            {
                // Notify Bluetooth peer
                
                struct custs1_val_ntf_ind_req* req2
                        = KE_MSG_ALLOC_DYN(CUSTS1_VAL_NTF_REQ, prf_get_task_from_id(TASK_ID_CUSTS1),
                                       TASK_APP, custs1_val_ntf_ind_req, 1);
                req2->notification = true;
                req2->conidx = app_env->conhdl;
                req2->handle = CUST1_IDX_FLOW_CONTROL_VAL;
                req2->length = 1;
                req2->value[0] = 0x01;
                ke_msg_send(req2);
                
                //user_send_remote_notification(CUST1_IDX_FLOW_CONTROL_VAL, 0x01, 0, 1);
            }
 
        }

    } else {
#ifdef AT_CONSOLE_PRINT_ERROR_MESSAGES			
        at_console_error_report(AT_CONSOLE_ERROR_7); // Tried to send to peer but no connection
        send_to_local(OK_TERMINATION_STRING);
#endif			
    }
}

Since void outbound_char_enqueue(const char* string_ptr) uses char* and string functions, which sees null as end of data, I am trying to send it using another way. Could you please help me send an array of data to remote BLE that would include null values.

Threads.Subject: DA14531 simple scan function
Threads.Body:
Hi,

I need a simple scan and try to find a device with specific address and get RSSI value.

Premade projects are just too confusing to understand.

I downloaded and tried to edit empty_peripheral_template project but stuck on scan process. I found a code but program freezes when "user_scan_start()" is called.

It would be great to have a clearer documentation instad of forcing users to find and extact code from premade projects and try to fix errors during implementation.

I also attach my code for reference.

Regards

/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 *
 * @file user_empty_peripheral_template.c
 *
 * @brief Empty peripheral template project source code.
 *
 * Copyright (C) 2012-2019 Dialog Semiconductor.
 * This computer program includes Confidential, Proprietary Information
 * of Dialog Semiconductor. All Rights Reserved.
 *
 ****************************************************************************************
 */

/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * @addtogroup APP
 * @{
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
#include "rwip_config.h"             // SW configuration
#include "llc_task.h"
#include "llc.h"

/*
 * INCLUDE FILES
 ****************************************************************************************
 */

#include "app_api.h"
#include "user_empty_peripheral_template.h"


#include "gpio.h"
#include "user_periph_setup.h"

#include "arch_console.h"
#define SAMPLE_AMOUNT 30

uint8_t m, array_filled_flag = 0;
int8_t rssi_array[SAMPLE_AMOUNT];
int rssi_value = 0, sum_rssi;
uint8_t app_connection_idx                      __SECTION_ZERO("retention_mem_area0"); //@RETENTION MEMORY
bool my_led_state __SECTION_ZERO("retention_mem_area0"); // @RETENTION MEMORY
bool connection_state = false;

struct bd_addr connected_device_address;

char bd_addrr[18]                                __SECTION_ZERO("retention_mem_area0"); //@RETENTION MEMORY

struct scan_configuration {
    /// Operation code.
    uint8_t     code;
    /// Own BD address source of the device
    uint8_t     addr_src;
    /// Scan interval
    uint16_t    interval;
    /// Scan window size
    uint16_t    window;
    /// Scanning mode
    uint8_t     mode;
    /// Scan filter policy
    uint8_t     filt_policy;
    /// Scan duplicate filtering policy
    uint8_t     filter_duplic;
};

static const struct scan_configuration user_scan_conf ={
    /// Operation code.
    .code = GAPM_SCAN_PASSIVE,
    /// Own BD address source of the device
    .addr_src = GAPM_STATIC_ADDR,
    /// Scan interval
    .interval = (USER_ADVERTISING_INT_MAX * 3) / 2,
    /// Scan window size
    .window = USER_ADVERTISING_INT_MIN/3,
    /// Scanning mode
    .mode = GAP_GEN_DISCOVERY,
    /// Scan filter policy
    .filt_policy = SCAN_ALLOW_ADV_ALL,
    /// Scan duplicate filtering policy
    .filter_duplic = SCAN_FILT_DUPLIC_EN
};

void user_scan_start( void );

/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * @brief Called upon device configuration complete message
 * @return void
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
void user_on_set_dev_config_complete( void )
{
		// start the scanning
		arch_printf( "Dev config complete\r\n");
		user_scan_start();
}


/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * @brief Start scanning for devices 
 * @return void
 ****************************************************************************************
 */




/*
 * FUNCTION DEFINITIONS
 ****************************************************************************************
*/



/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * @brief Scan complete function. Restart the scanning
 * @return void
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
void user_on_scan_complete(const uint8_t param){
    arch_puts( "SCAN COMPLETE\r\n");
		user_scan_start();
}

void user_adv_report_ind (struct gapm_adv_report_ind const * param ) {
	uint8_t ad_len,index=0;
	
	// report the bluetooth device address
	arch_printf( "[%02x:%02x:%02x:",  (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[5], (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[4], (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[3] );
  arch_printf( "%02x:%02x:%02x] ", (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[2], (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[1], (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[0] );
		
	// report the advertising payload length
	arch_printf("LEN %d\r\n",param->report.data_len);
		
	// loop through the advertising data information
	while( index < param->report.data_len) {
		
		// extract field length
		ad_len = param->report.data[index];
		arch_printf( "  - ");
		
		// decode field type
		if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x9) {                // Device name
			arch_printf( "Name: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%c", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x1) {        // Device flags
			arch_printf( "Flags: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x3 || param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x2) { // Services 16 bits UUID
			arch_printf( "Services ID: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i+=2) {
				arch_printf("0x%X%X, ", param->report.data[i+1],param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x7) {       // Services 128 bits UUID
			arch_printf( "128 Bits UUID: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x15) {     // Services solicitation 128 bits UUID
			arch_printf( "128 Bits solicitation UUID: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0xFF) {    // Manufacturer specific data
			arch_printf( "Manufacture Specific: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else {                                              // not decoded raw data
			arch_printf( "%X:", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		}
		
		arch_puts( "\r\n");
		index += ad_len + 1;
	} 
    
}


void user_app_on_init(void)
{
	arch_puts("Run\n\r");
    my_led_state = true;
    // Set sleep mode
		
	user_scan_start();
    default_app_on_init();
}


void control_LED(bool state)
{
    if(state == true)
        GPIO_SetActive(LED_PORT,LED_PIN);
    else
        GPIO_SetInactive(LED_PORT,LED_PIN);
		
		my_led_state = state;

}

void my_timer_cb()
{
   //control_LED(false);
	
	
	rssi_array[m] = ReadRssi();
	m++;
	if(m == SAMPLE_AMOUNT)
	{ 
		m = 0; 
		array_filled_flag = 1;
	}
	
	for(uint8_t count = 0; count < SAMPLE_AMOUNT; count++){
		sum_rssi+=rssi_array[count];
	}
	if(array_filled_flag)rssi_value = sum_rssi / SAMPLE_AMOUNT;
	sum_rssi = 0;
	
	if(rssi_value < -80) control_LED(false);
	else control_LED(true);
		
	arch_printf("RSSI Value = %d\n\r", rssi_value); 
	if(connection_state)app_easy_timer(5, my_timer_cb);
	
}

void user_on_connection(uint8_t connection_idx, struct gapc_connection_req_ind const *param)
{
  default_app_on_connection(connection_idx, param);
	connection_state = true;
	//if(GPIO_GetPinStatus(BTN_PORT, BTN_PIN))     //BUNU DENEYECEGIZ
		
	arch_puts("Stage1\n\r");
	control_LED(true);
	arch_puts("Someone Connected\n\r");
	app_connection_idx = connection_idx;
	
  memcpy(&connected_device_address.addr, &param->peer_addr.addr, 6);
	
	arch_puts("address = "); 
	for (int i = 0; i < 6; i++) {
    arch_printf("%d ", connected_device_address.addr[i]);     
  } 
	arch_puts("\n\r");
	
	
		//user_scan_start();
	
	app_easy_timer(200, my_timer_cb); // 200*10ms lik bir timer baslatildi. Timer bitince my_timer_cb() cagiriliyor.

}

void user_on_disconnect( struct gapc_disconnect_ind const *param )
{
    default_app_on_disconnect(param);
		control_LED(false);
		connection_state = false;
		arch_puts("Someone Disconnected\n\r");
}
 
void user_get_bdaddr( struct bd_addr *address )
{
    struct bd_addr tempAddr = {0xEE,0xFF,0xC0,0xEE,0xFF,0xC0};
    memcpy(address, &tempAddr, 6);
}

int8_t ReadRssi(void)
{            
    int8_t local_rssi = 0;
    if (ke_state_get(KE_BUILD_ID(TASK_LLC, gapc_get_conhdl(app_connection_idx)))== LLC_CONNECTED)
    {               
			
				//arch_puts("Getting RSSI Value\n\r");
        // Get the RSSI value
        local_rssi = (int8_t) llc_env[gapc_get_conhdl(app_connection_idx)]->rssi;

    }
    return local_rssi;
}

/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * @brief Start scanning for devices 
 * @return void
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
static void user_scan_start(void)
{
    struct gapm_start_scan_cmd* cmd = KE_MSG_ALLOC(GAPM_START_SCAN_CMD,
                                                   TASK_GAPM,
                                                   TASK_APP,
                                                   gapm_start_scan_cmd);

    cmd->op.code = user_scan_conf.code;
    cmd->op.addr_src = user_scan_conf.addr_src;
    cmd->interval = user_scan_conf.interval;
    cmd->window = user_scan_conf.window;
    cmd->mode = user_scan_conf.mode;
    cmd->filt_policy = user_scan_conf.filt_policy;
    cmd->filter_duplic =user_scan_conf.filter_duplic;
    
    arch_puts("\r\nSCANNING\n\r");
    
    // Send the message
    ke_msg_send(cmd);

    // We are now connectable
    ke_state_set(TASK_APP, APP_CONNECTABLE);
    
    #if USER_SCANNING_TIMEOUT
    int8_t rand_val = (int8_t) co_rand_byte();
    user_scan_timeout_timer = app_easy_timer(USER_SCANNING_TO + rand_val, user_scanning_timeout_timer_cb);
    #endif
}

/// @} APP

uint8_t app_connection_idx                      __SECTION_ZERO("retention_mem_area0"); //@RETENTION MEMORY
bool my_led_state __SECTION_ZERO("retention_mem_area0"); // @RETENTION MEMORY
bool connection_state = false;

struct bd_addr connected_device_address;

char bd_addrr[18]                                __SECTION_ZERO("retention_mem_area0"); //@RETENTION MEMORY

struct scan_configuration {
    /// Operation code.
    uint8_t     code;
    /// Own BD address source of the device
    uint8_t     addr_src;
    /// Scan interval
    uint16_t    interval;
    /// Scan window size
    uint16_t    window;
    /// Scanning mode
    uint8_t     mode;
    /// Scan filter policy
    uint8_t     filt_policy;
    /// Scan duplicate filtering policy
    uint8_t     filter_duplic;
};

static const struct scan_configuration user_scan_conf ={
    /// Operation code.
    .code = GAPM_SCAN_PASSIVE,
    /// Own BD address source of the device
    .addr_src = GAPM_STATIC_ADDR,
    /// Scan interval
    .interval = (USER_ADVERTISING_INT_MAX * 3) / 2,
    /// Scan window size
    .window = USER_ADVERTISING_INT_MIN/3,
    /// Scanning mode
    .mode = GAP_GEN_DISCOVERY,
    /// Scan filter policy
    .filt_policy = SCAN_ALLOW_ADV_ALL,
    /// Scan duplicate filtering policy
    .filter_duplic = SCAN_FILT_DUPLIC_EN
};

void user_scan_start( void );

/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * @brief Called upon device configuration complete message
 * @return void
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
void user_on_set_dev_config_complete( void )
{
		// start the scanning
		arch_printf( "Dev config complete\r\n");
		user_scan_start();
}


/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * @brief Start scanning for devices 
 * @return void
 ****************************************************************************************
 */




/*
 * FUNCTION DEFINITIONS
 ****************************************************************************************
*/



/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * @brief Scan complete function. Restart the scanning
 * @return void
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
void user_on_scan_complete(const uint8_t param){
    arch_puts( "SCAN COMPLETE\r\n");
		user_scan_start();
}

void user_adv_report_ind (struct gapm_adv_report_ind const * param ) {
	uint8_t ad_len,index=0;
	
	// report the bluetooth device address
	arch_printf( "[%02x:%02x:%02x:",  (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[5], (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[4], (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[3] );
  arch_printf( "%02x:%02x:%02x] ", (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[2], (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[1], (int)param->report.adv_addr.addr[0] );
		
	// report the advertising payload length
	arch_printf("LEN %d\r\n",param->report.data_len);
		
	// loop through the advertising data information
	while( index < param->report.data_len) {
		
		// extract field length
		ad_len = param->report.data[index];
		arch_printf( "  - ");
		
		// decode field type
		if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x9) {                // Device name
			arch_printf( "Name: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%c", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x1) {        // Device flags
			arch_printf( "Flags: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x3 || param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x2) { // Services 16 bits UUID
			arch_printf( "Services ID: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i+=2) {
				arch_printf("0x%X%X, ", param->report.data[i+1],param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x7) {       // Services 128 bits UUID
			arch_printf( "128 Bits UUID: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0x15) {     // Services solicitation 128 bits UUID
			arch_printf( "128 Bits solicitation UUID: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else if(param->report.data[index + 1 ] == 0xFF) {    // Manufacturer specific data
			arch_printf( "Manufacture Specific: ", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		} else {                                              // not decoded raw data
			arch_printf( "%X:", param->report.data[index + 1 ]);
			for(int i= index + 2; i < index + ad_len + 1; i++) {
				arch_printf("%X ", param->report.data[i]);
			}
		}
		
		arch_puts( "\r\n");
		index += ad_len + 1;
	} 
    
}


void user_app_on_init(void)
{
	arch_puts("Run\n\r");
    my_led_state = true;
    // Set sleep mode
		
	user_scan_start();
    default_app_on_init();
}


void control_LED(bool state)
{
    if(state == true)
        GPIO_SetActive(LED_PORT,LED_PIN);
    else
        GPIO_SetInactive(LED_PORT,LED_PIN);
		
		my_led_state = state;

}

void my_timer_cb()
{
   //control_LED(false);
	
	
	rssi_array[m] = ReadRssi();
	m++;
	if(m == SAMPLE_AMOUNT)
	{ 
		m = 0; 
		array_filled_flag = 1;
	}
	
	for(uint8_t count = 0; count < SAMPLE_AMOUNT; count++){
		sum_rssi+=rssi_array[count];
	}
	if(array_filled_flag)rssi_value = sum_rssi / SAMPLE_AMOUNT;
	sum_rssi = 0;
	
	if(rssi_value < -80) control_LED(false);
	else control_LED(true);
		
	arch_printf("RSSI Value = %d\n\r", rssi_value); 
	if(connection_state)app_easy_timer(5, my_timer_cb);
	
}

void user_on_connection(uint8_t connection_idx, struct gapc_connection_req_ind const *param)
{
  default_app_on_connection(connection_idx, param);
	connection_state = true;
	//if(GPIO_GetPinStatus(BTN_PORT, BTN_PIN))     //BUNU DENEYECEGIZ
		
	arch_puts("Stage1\n\r");
	control_LED(true);
	arch_puts("Someone Connected\n\r");
	app_connection_idx = connection_idx;
	
  memcpy(&connected_device_address.addr, &param->peer_addr.addr, 6);
	
	arch_puts("address = "); 
	for (int i = 0; i < 6; i++) {
    arch_printf("%d ", connected_device_address.addr[i]);     
  } 
	arch_puts("\n\r");
	
	
		//user_scan_start();
	
	app_easy_timer(200, my_timer_cb); // 200*10ms lik bir timer baslatildi. Timer bitince my_timer_cb() cagiriliyor.

}

void user_on_disconnect( struct gapc_disconnect_ind const *param )
{
    default_app_on_disconnect(param);
		control_LED(false);
		connection_state = false;
		arch_puts("Someone Disconnected\n\r");
}
 
void user_get_bdaddr( struct bd_addr *address )
{
    struct bd_addr tempAddr = {0xEE,0xFF,0xC0,0xEE,0xFF,0xC0};
    memcpy(address, &tempAddr, 6);
}

int8_t ReadRssi(void)
{            
    int8_t local_rssi = 0;
    if (ke_state_get(KE_BUILD_ID(TASK_LLC, gapc_get_conhdl(app_connection_idx)))== LLC_CONNECTED)
    {               
			
				//arch_puts("Getting RSSI Value\n\r");
        // Get the RSSI value
        local_rssi = (int8_t) llc_env[gapc_get_conhdl(app_connection_idx)]->rssi;

    }
    return local_rssi;
}

/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * @brief Start scanning for devices 
 * @return void
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
static void user_scan_start(void)
{
    struct gapm_start_scan_cmd* cmd = KE_MSG_ALLOC(GAPM_START_SCAN_CMD,
                                                   TASK_GAPM,
                                                   TASK_APP,
                                                   gapm_start_scan_cmd);

    cmd->op.code = user_scan_conf.code;
    cmd->op.addr_src = user_scan_conf.addr_src;
    cmd->interval = user_scan_conf.interval;
    cmd->window = user_scan_conf.window;
    cmd->mode = user_scan_conf.mode;
    cmd->filt_policy = user_scan_conf.filt_policy;
    cmd->filter_duplic =user_scan_conf.filter_duplic;
    
    arch_puts("\r\nSCANNING\n\r");
    
    // Send the message
    ke_msg_send(cmd);

    // We are now connectable
    ke_state_set(TASK_APP, APP_CONNECTABLE);
    
    #if USER_SCANNING_TIMEOUT
    int8_t rand_val = (int8_t) co_rand_byte();
    user_scan_timeout_timer = app_easy_timer(USER_SCANNING_TO + rand_val, user_scanning_timeout_timer_cb);
    #endif
}

/// @} APP

Threads.Subject: DA1469x new AA revision and SDK 10.0.10.118 compatibility
Threads.Body:
Hello,

We have a product we are manufacturing  & selling continuously based on DA14691 and SDK 10.0.10.118. We just found out that the new chips of the same type have different revision (AA instead of AB).

Base boundary condition: we don't want to switch to the new SDK (10.0.12.146), due to the workload needed for migration, testing and risk. As it stands now, the firmware based on the old SDK does not function with the new chips.

My question are:

- is the old SDK compatible with the new revision chips, after modifying the is_compatible_chip_version() function? (I guess not, due to the new cmac)

- if not, what is the minimum amount of code that has to be taken from the new SDK to guarantee working firmware both with old and new revision chips?

- If this is not possible, what is the date after which the chips have new revision?

Also: How come we haven't heard of this in a newsletter with big red exclamation marks? We receive a large amount of everything from you, but nothing from an update which breaks currently running production based on previous SDK?

Regards,

Threads.Subject: BLE advertising start and stop
Threads.Body:
Hi,

I am using DA14531 with SDK Version: 6.0.16.1144. I need to advertise only when a switch connected to the GPIO is pressed.

I am reading the switch using timer call back function in every 1 second. I am using the app_easy_timer for reading call back.

static void switch_update_timer_cb()
{
	if(GPIO_GetPinStatus(GPIO_PHE_PORT, BLE_PIN) == 0)
	{
		user_app_adv_start();
	}
	
	switch_update_timer_used = app_easy_timer(SWITCH_UPDATE_REQUEST_TO, switch_update_timer_cb);
}

So I am calling the "user_app_adv_start();" function only when the switch pressed, also commented it in other functions as you can see below

void user_app_adv_start(void)
{
    // Schedule the next advertising data update
    app_adv_data_update_timer_used = app_easy_timer(APP_ADV_DATA_UPDATE_TO, adv_data_update_timer_cb);
		switch_update_timer_used = app_easy_timer(SWITCH_UPDATE_REQUEST_TO, switch_update_timer_cb);

    struct gapm_start_advertise_cmd* cmd;
    cmd = app_easy_gap_undirected_advertise_get_active();

    // Add manufacturer data to initial advertising or scan response data, if there is enough space
    app_add_ad_struct(cmd, &mnf_data, sizeof(struct mnf_specific_data_ad_structure), 1);

    app_easy_gap_undirected_advertise_start();
}
void user_app_connection(uint8_t connection_idx, struct gapc_connection_req_ind const *param)
{
		rtc_time_t time;
		rtc_calendar_t clndr;

		/* Read time and date from on-chip RTC */
		rtc_get_time_clndr(&time, &clndr);
	
    if (app_env[connection_idx].conidx != GAP_INVALID_CONIDX)
    {
        app_connection_idx = connection_idx;

        // Stop the advertising data update timer
        app_easy_timer_cancel(app_adv_data_update_timer_used);

        // Check if the parameters of the established connection are the preferred ones.
        // If not then schedule a connection parameter update request.
        if ((param->con_interval < user_connection_param_conf.intv_min) ||
            (param->con_interval > user_connection_param_conf.intv_max) ||
            (param->con_latency != user_connection_param_conf.latency) ||
            (param->sup_to != user_connection_param_conf.time_out))
        {
            // Connection params are not these that we expect
            app_param_update_request_timer_used = app_easy_timer(APP_PARAM_UPDATE_REQUEST_TO, param_update_request_timer_cb);
        }
    }
//    else
//    {
//        // No connection has been established, restart advertising
//        user_app_adv_start();
//    }

    default_app_on_connection(connection_idx, param);
}

void user_app_adv_undirect_complete(uint8_t status)
{
    // If advertising was canceled then update advertising data and start advertising again
    if (status == GAP_ERR_CANCELED)
    {
        //user_app_adv_start();
    }
}

void user_app_disconnect(struct gapc_disconnect_ind const *param)
{
    // Cancel the parameter update request timer
    if (app_param_update_request_timer_used != EASY_TIMER_INVALID_TIMER)
    {
        app_easy_timer_cancel(app_param_update_request_timer_used);
        app_param_update_request_timer_used = EASY_TIMER_INVALID_TIMER;
    }
    // Update manufacturer data for the next advertsing event
    mnf_data_update();
    // Restart Advertising
    //user_app_adv_start();
}

Everything is working fine for 10 to 12 hrs. But if I keep the board running for more than one day, the app_easy_timer is not responding and the device is not advertising as well.

What could be the issue?

Is there any suitable method for starting the advertisement using an external button?

Thank,

Abhi

        {

            app_param_update_request_timer_used = app_easy_timer(APP_PARAM_UPDATE_REQUEST_TO, param_update_request_timer_cb);
        }
    }
//    else
//    {
//        // No connection has been established, restart advertising
//        user_app_adv_start();
//    }

    default_app_on_connection(connection_idx, param);
}

void user_app_adv_undirect_complete(uint8_t status)
{
    // If advertising was canceled then update advertising data and start advertising again
    if (status == GAP_ERR_CANCELED)
    {
        //user_app_adv_start();
    }
}

void user_app_disconnect(struct gapc_disconnect_ind const *param)
{
    // Cancel the parameter update request timer
    if (app_param_update_request_timer_used != EASY_TIMER_INVALID_TIMER)
    {
        app_easy_timer_cancel(app_param_update_request_timer_used);
        app_param_update_request_timer_used = EASY_TIMER_INVALID_TIMER;
    }
    // Update manufacturer data for the next advertsing event
    mnf_data_update();
    // Restart Advertising
    //user_app_adv_start();
}

Everything is working fine for 10 to 12 hrs. But if I keep the board running for more than one day, the app_easy_timer is not responding and the device is not advertising as well.

What could be the issue?

Is there any suitable method for starting the advertisement using an external button?

Thank,

Abhi

Threads.Subject: Getting SPI_FLASH_ERR_WEL_ERROR when writing to flash from custs1
Threads.Body:
Hello,

In my project, the user is able to change the device name. I used this as a starting point: https://community.renesas.com/wireles-connectivity/f/bluetooth-low-energy/30602/da14531-name-change-service-characteristic, which works fine.

However, I want to be able to save the device name to the flash as well, so I can read it during initialization, so it can keep the new name even after being turned completely off. However, whenever I try to write during custs1, I get strange write errors.

In order to rule out other issues, I started from scratch with the SPI Flash tutorial: https://lpccs-docs.renesas.com/da145xx_tutorial_sdk6_peripherals/da14531_spi_flash.html

My issue is now the following:

- When I run the code (under "Putting it all together") in user_on_init, it works as expected.

- When I run the exact same code in user_svc1_dev_name_wr_ind_handler (from the community post linked above), I get SPI_FLASH_ERR_WEL_ERROR.

This is the output I get:

user_on_init

Erase Status: 0
Write Status: 0
Bytes Written: 8
Read Status: 0
Bytes Read: 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
user_svc1_dev_name_wr_ind_handler

Erase Status: -12
Write Status: -12
Bytes Written: 0
Read Status: 0
Bytes Read: 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0

What am I doing wrong? Shouldn't I be able to write to the flash while in a characteristic write method?

Threads.Subject: Build and debug in VSCode for DA145XX
Threads.Body:
Hi Folks,

This repository contains examples and readme explaining how to build and debug DA145XX projects in VSCode + GDB. 

Note - I have only tested iBeacon, Central and Barebone examples on DA14531 USB kit and while they all worked out of the box, your mileage may vary - it may not work for other targets or your custom board. 6.0.18.1182.1 SDK has been used for testing. 

You will find detailed instructions in readme but fundamentally all you need to do:

- clone my two repos into the right place within Renesas SDK;

- copy CMakeLists.txt and .vscode folder from either iBeacon or Central (only two that have been modified) into the project example of your choice.

- Edit both files to match your installation

- Configure, build, run. Ta-da!

All above of course assumes that you have VSCode, CMake and GNU arm-none-eabi toolchain installed and configured. Same process for the 'proprietary' examples inside Renesas SDK. Just copy those two files over.

If you are on Mac or Linux and built CMake projects in VSCode before, it should take less than half a hour to give it a try, If not and you are on Windows, make sure CMake is functional first. I personally suggest installing everything via MinGW - pacman, but it is the matter of choice.

IMPORTANT: It's a freebee - no warranty whatsoever of any kind or support. So far it looks promising but there might be hidden issues I am not yet aware of. On a plus side - no code size limit or license restrictions. And cross-platform ( tested on Mac).

Enjoy

Threads.Subject: DA14695 - SPI still Busy after Write
Threads.Body:
Hi,

This is Abishekh. I am currently working with DA14695 USB Kit and trying to interface with a sensor.

After writing a large chunk of code through SPI (around 5000 bytes), I reset the sensor to start its operation. This is the usual flow.

So, after resetting the sensor, It interrupts my controller, and I have to issue a write command to the sensor for it to start operation. But while trying to write this command, SPI Bus is Busy, though I did not use ASYNC SPI operations. Basically After writing a large chunk, SPI did not reset properly.  

Is this a known Issue & related to the SPI not restarting issue, as mentioned in the latest errata, Issue number 3

I am on the latest version of SDK (SDK_10.0.12.146.2) and latest version of Smartsnippets studio IDE V 2.0.20.4060. 

Regards,

Abishekh

Threads.Subject: DA14706 reporting an incompatible SWC level of 0
Threads.Body:
I am brining up a prototype board with a DA14706 A1 cpu.  Serial and jtag loading to qspi both fail after the initial bootloader is loaded.   Loading an example application to RAM and debugging it results in an error in pre startup here:

bool hw_sys_is_compatible_chip(void)
{
#ifndef POPULATE_DEVICE_INFO
        return true;
#else
        if (hw_sys_device_info_check(DEVICE_CHIP_ID_MASK, DEVICE_CHIP_ID_2798)) {
                if (hw_sys_device_info_check(DEVICE_REVISION_MASK, DEVICE_REV_A) &&
                    hw_sys_device_info_check(DEVICE_SWC_MASK, DEVICE_SWC_1)) {
                        return true;
                }
        } else if (hw_sys_device_info_check(DEVICE_CHIP_ID_MASK, DEVICE_CHIP_ID_3107)) {
                if (hw_sys_device_info_check(DEVICE_REVISION_MASK, DEVICE_REV_A) &&
                    hw_sys_device_info_check(DEVICE_SWC_MASK, DEVICE_SWC_0)) {
                        return true;
                }
        }

        return false;
#endif
}

This is called from SystemInitPre()

When this is executed the chip id evaluates to 2798 and the revision mask to A.  However, the SWC evaluates to SWC_0 which causes the assertion to fail and the device to hang.  Forcing it to return true always causes it to hang later on in an NMI.

I am at a loss.

Threads.Subject: Making a "Device Unique IRK" function for robust RPA implementation
Threads.Body:
Hello Renesas forum, are anyone down to cooperate on making a unique IRK function for the DA14531, specifically for the DA14531MOD ?

In the examples, all IRK are 

    /// Device IRK used for Resolvable Private Address generation (LSB first)
    .irk = {0x00, 0x01, 0x02, 0x03, 0x04, 0x05, 0x06, 0x07, 0x08, 0x09, 0x0a, 0x0b, 0x0c, 0x0d, 0x0e, 0x0f},

As there's no public, copy pasta, implementation for dummies for DA14531 in SDK 6.0.20 i would like to cooperate on creating code available to all on the forum in this post.

From previous Renesas support guidance i have learned that:

  • IRK should be unique to each device
  • It should be randomly generated by TRNG and stored for future use on the SPI Flash
  • It should all be handled in user_app_init in the user app
  • It should be inspired by the conversations, and sources in the following posts:
    • https://community.renesas.com/wireles-connectivity/f/bluetooth-low-energy/32308/random-irk-generation-functions-for-pairing-devices 
    • https://community.renesas.com/wireles-connectivity/f/bluetooth-low-energy/32531/understanding-multi-bonding-and-differentiation-of-rpa-devices-in-sdk-6-0-20-ble_app_security-for-da14531mod/114914#114914

This is supposed to be simple, and i need to figure out the following:

  1. What address on the Da14531MOD SPI-Flash to store the IRK on
  2. How to check if there already is a 128bit IRK stored on the address
  3. How to make a 128bit IRK using the TRNG function
  4. How to store the IRK on the address
  5. How to read the IRK from the address
  6. How to write the IRK into user_gapm_conf.irk in user_config.h
  7. All of this without interfering with other processes, though the assumption is that it'l be fine as it is contained in the user_app_init callback function.

As a novice, I'll try on my own, and post what i've made if i succeed. If anyone has pastable code to contribute, please do - and feel free to chime in with constructive criticism. the primary objectives of this post is accelerating making the Unique IRK implementation and making it available to all, as it is universally recommended by Renesas when using RPA.

Threads.Subject: Undetected Device when add Some code
Threads.Body:
Hello!
I have developed a simple application to read 2 ADC voltages basically and send them to a central...
I had already finished it and I wanted to add a gpio output that activates a mosfet in my hardware...
I added it as follows:

/****************************************************************************************/
/* LED configuration */
/****************************************************************************************/
#if defined (__DA14531__)
#define GPIO_LED_PORT GPIO_PORT_0
#define GPIO_LED_PIN GPIO_PIN_9
#define ADC_INPUT_PORT GPIO_PORT_0
#define ADC_INPUT_PIN GPIO_PIN_6
#define BRIDGE_CTRL_PORT GPIO_PORT_0
#define BRIDGE_CTRL_PIN GPIO_PIN_11
#else
#define GPIO_LED_PORT GPIO_PORT_1
#define GPIO_LED_PIN GPIO_PIN_0
#endif

And the reservation...

#if DEVELOPMENT_DEBUG

void GPIO_reservations(void)
{
RESERVE_GPIO(LED, GPIO_LED_PORT, GPIO_LED_PIN, PID_GPIO);
RESERVE_GPIO(BRIDGE_W, BRIDGE_CTRL_PORT , BRIDGE_CTRL_PIN, PID_GPIO);


/*
i.e. to reserve P0_1 as Generic Purpose I/O:
RESERVE_GPIO(DESCRIPTIVE_NAME, GPIO_PORT_0, GPIO_PIN_1, PID_GPIO);
*/

#if defined (CFG_PRINTF_UART2)

I then use my GPIO output as follows in "user_cuts1_impl.c":

void app_adcval1_timer_cb_handler()
{
struct custs1_val_ntf_ind_req *req = KE_MSG_ALLOC_DYN(CUSTS1_VAL_NTF_REQ,
prf_get_task_from_id(TASK_ID_CUSTS1),
TASK_APP,
custs1_val_ntf_ind_req,
DEF_SVC1_ADC_VAL_1_CHAR_LEN);
// Disable the Extended Sleep Mode so ADC can work as expected
arch_set_sleep_mode(ARCH_SLEEP_OFF);
GPIO_SetActive(BRIDGE_CTRL_PORT, BRIDGE_CTRL_PIN); //ACTIVE BRIDGE CURRENT
//DELAY
// ADC value to be sampled


//new
/* Perform single ADC conversion */

uint16_t result = gpadc_read();
uint16_t adc_val_mv = gpadc_sample_to_mv(result);
//A PARTIR DEL ADC CONVERTIR PERO EN aNDROID A TEMPERATURA Y MOSTRAR
//float adc_val_V= adc_val_mv/1000.0;
//float Rmedida= (adc_val_V/(Vref/2))*R_ref;
//float Temp= (Rmedida / R0_PT1000 -1.0) / alpha_PT1000;
//uint16_t Final_temp= (uint16_t) Temp;
contador++;
if(contador >= 10){
contador=0;
}
//Enable the Extended Sleep mode again for better current consumption
GPIO_SetInactive(BRIDGE_CTRL_PORT, BRIDGE_CTRL_PIN); //INACTIVE BRIDGE CURRENT
arch_set_sleep_mode(ARCH_EXT_SLEEP_ON);

//req->conhdl = app_env->conhdl;
req->handle = SVC1_IDX_ADC_VAL_1_VAL;
req->length = DEF_SVC1_ADC_VAL_1_CHAR_LEN;
req->notification = true;
/*Change the value updated with adc_val_mv */


memcpy(req->value, &adc_val_mv, DEF_SVC1_ADC_VAL_1_CHAR_LEN); //replace "sample" for value required

ke_msg_send(req);

if (ke_state_get(TASK_APP) == APP_CONNECTED)
{
// Set it once again until Stop command is received in Control Characteristic
timer_used = app_easy_timer(APP_PERIPHERAL_CTRL_TIMER_DELAY, app_adcval1_timer_cb_handler);
}
}

I didn't really add or do anything else....
I thought that by some hardware error I had damaged my DA14531MOD, so I changed it and the new one let me program it the first time and when I tried to read it again to program it, again the message "undetected" appears in flash programmer... I tried with a hardware where I only have the DA14531MOD and the programming pins without more components and the same thing happens, the first time it detects it and lets it program, but after loading the program the same thing happens:

I am really worried since I discarded one module because I thought I had damaged it and I would only have one left to continue....
I don't know if maybe I have some conceptual error with gpioreservations or what happens in memory when uploading my code? I appreciate your help... Thank you.

req->handle = SVC1_IDX_ADC_VAL_1_VAL;
req->length = DEF_SVC1_ADC_VAL_1_CHAR_LEN;
req->notification = true;
/*Change the value updated with adc_val_mv */


memcpy(req->value, &adc_val_mv, DEF_SVC1_ADC_VAL_1_CHAR_LEN); //replace "sample" for value required

ke_msg_send(req);

if (ke_state_get(TASK_APP) == APP_CONNECTED)
{
// Set it once again until Stop command is received in Control Characteristic
timer_used = app_easy_timer(APP_PERIPHERAL_CTRL_TIMER_DELAY, app_adcval1_timer_cb_handler);
}
}

I didn't really add or do anything else....
I thought that by some hardware error I had damaged my DA14531MOD, so I changed it and the new one let me program it the first time and when I tried to read it again to program it, again the message "undetected" appears in flash programmer... I tried with a hardware where I only have the DA14531MOD and the programming pins without more components and the same thing happens, the first time it detects it and lets it program, but after loading the program the same thing happens:

I am really worried since I discarded one module because I thought I had damaged it and I would only have one left to continue....
I don't know if maybe I have some conceptual error with gpioreservations or what happens in memory when uploading my code? I appreciate your help... Thank you.

Threads.Subject: DA14531 Wake Up From Deep Sleep (SPI Flash)
Threads.Body:
Hi;

We used Da14531 + SPI Flash in our project. We put the device in deep mode in some conditions.  
We enable the WakeUp Controller for the button and put the deep microcontroller to sleep.

Then when we press the button, the microcontroller wakes up but the application does not work. It stays in reset state. When we Power-Reset, it can boot and run again over spi flash.

Wake-Up Enable Function:

        wkupct_enable_irq( WKUPCT_PIN_SELECT(BUTTON_PORT, BUTTON_PIN),\
        WKUPCT_PIN_POLARITY(BUTTON_PORT, BUTTON_PIN, WKUPCT_PIN_POLARITY_LOW),\
        1,10);

Deep Sleep Set Function:

arch_set_deep_sleep(PD_SYS_DOWN_RAM_OFF, PD_SYS_DOWN_RAM_OFF, PD_SYS_DOWN_RAM_OFF, false);

Best Regards...

/**
 ****************************************************************************************

#include "hogpd.h"
#include "hogpd_task.h"

#define HID_DUMMY_REPORT_ID				        0x00 // dummy report
#define HID_DUMMY_REPORT_SIZE   		        8    // The size of the dummy report

#define HID_KEYBOARD_REPORT_ID     		        0x01 // keyboard input report
#define HID_KEYBOARD_REPORT_SIZE   		        8    // The size of the keyboard input report

#define HID_KEYBOARD_OUTPUT_REPORT_ID     		0x02 // keyboard report
#define HID_KEYBOARD_OUTPUT_REPORT_SIZE   		1    // The size of the keyboard report


enum hogpd_indexes {
	HID_DUMMY_REPORT_IDX,
	HID_KEYBOARD_REPORT_IDX,
    HID_KEYBOARD_REPORT_OUTPUT_IDX,
    HID_NUM_OF_REPORTS // Don't remove this.
};

void hid_output_report_write_callback(uint8_t conidx, struct hogpd_report_info *report_info);
static const hogpd_reports_t hogpd_reports[HID_NUM_OF_REPORTS] = 
{

	[HID_DUMMY_REPORT_IDX]       = {.id             = HID_DUMMY_REPORT_ID,           
                                    .size           = HID_DUMMY_REPORT_SIZE,     
                                    .cfg            = HOGPD_CFG_REPORT_IN | HOGPD_REPORT_NTF_CFG_MASK | HOGPD_CFG_REPORT_WR,

                                    .write_callback = NULL},

	[HID_KEYBOARD_REPORT_IDX]    = {.id             = HID_KEYBOARD_REPORT_ID,

                                    .read_callback  = NULL,
                                    .write_callback = NULL},
    
    [HID_KEYBOARD_REPORT_OUTPUT_IDX]    = {.id          = HID_KEYBOARD_OUTPUT_REPORT_ID,           
                                        .size           = HID_KEYBOARD_OUTPUT_REPORT_SIZE,     
                                        .cfg            = HOGPD_CFG_REPORT_OUT, 
                                        .read_callback  = NULL,
                                        .write_callback = hid_output_report_write_callback},	                                    	

};

static const hogpd_params_t hogpd_params = {
/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * Use BOOT MODE                                                                        
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
    .boot_protocol_mode   = false,
        
/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * Include BATT in HID                                                                  
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
    .batt_external_report = false,
        
/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * Set RemoteWakeup mode. Remote Host may not handle properly remote wakeup when the 
 * inactivity timeout is on. Some Hosts do not expect to receive LL_TERMINATE_IND from 
 * Wakeup capable devices while they are sleeping.
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
    .remote_wakeup        = false,
        
/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * Set normally connectable mode                                                                
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
#ifdef NORMALLY_CONNECTABLE    
    .normally_connectable = true,
#else
    .normally_connectable = false,
#endif  
  
/**
 ****************************************************************************************
 * \brief Callback for storing CCC and attributes
 ****************************************************************************************
 */
#ifdef HAS_CONNECTION_FSM
    .store_attribute_callback = user_store_ccc,
#else
    .store_attribute_callback = NULL,
#endif
};


// Report Descriptor == Report Map (HID1_11.pdf section E.6)
static const uint8_t report_map[]  =
{
0x05, 0x01, /* 		Usage Page (Generic Desktop)        */
0x09, 0x06, /*		Usage (Keyboard)                    */
0xA1, 0x01, /*		Collection (Application)            */

0x85, 0x01, /*      REPORT_ID (1)                       */
0x05, 0x07, /*  	Usage (Key codes)                   */
0x19, 0xE0, /*      Usage Minimum (224)                 */
0x29, 0xE7, /*      Usage Maximum (231)                 */
0x15, 0x00, /*      Logical Minimum (0)                 */
0x25, 0x01, /*      Logical Maximum (1)                 */
0x75, 0x01, /*      Report Size (1)                     */
0x95, 0x08, /*      Report Count (8)                    */
0x81, 0x02, /*      Input (Data, Variable, Absolute)    */
0x95, 0x01, /*      Report Count (1)                    */
0x75, 0x08, /*      Report Size (8)                     */
0x81, 0x01, /*      Input (Constant)                    */
0x95, 0x06, /*      Report Count (6)                    */
0x75, 0x08, /*      Report Size (8)                     */
0x15, 0x00, /*      Logical Minimum (0)                 */
0x25, 0x65, /*      Logical Maximum (101)               */
0x05, 0x07, /*  	Usage (Key codes)                   */
0x19, 0x00, /*      Usage Minimum (00)                  */
0x29, 0x65, /*      Usage Maximum (101)                 */
0x81, 0x00, /*      Input (Data, Array)                 */

//* LED
0x85, 0x02, /*      REPORT_ID (2)                       */
0x05, 0x08, /*      Usage Page (Page# for LEDs)         */
0x19, 0x01, /*      Usage Minimum (01)                  */
0x29, 0x05, /*      Usage Maximum (05)                  */
0x95, 0x05, /*      Report Count (5)                    */
0x75, 0x01, /*      Report Size (1)                     */
0x91, 0x02, /*      Output (Data, Variable, Absolute)   */
0x95, 0x01, /*      Report Count (1)                    */
0x75, 0x03, /*      Report Size (3)                     */
0x91, 0x01, /*      Output (Constant)                   */

0xC0,      /* 		End Collection,End Collection       */              // End Collection
};

#endif // _USER_HOGPD_CONFIG_H_

Threads.Subject: SmartSnippets unable to detect JTAG on new computer
Threads.Body:
Hi, I'm having difficulty connecting to a JLINK programmer using SmartSnippets v5.0.22.4084 on a new computer.

On computer 1, I go to Board-> JTAG->(serial number)

On computer 2, when I hover over JTAG, no serial number appears. However, if i go to Board->JTAG->Device Info, then click JTAG info in the popup window, the JTAG Is present and detected (with serial number). 

Has anyone seen this problem before? I've used multiple USB ports and also see the JLINK in my device manager, so I am confident the drivers are installed correctly.

In both instance, I am connected to the PC over USB but not to a device to program. Thank you

Threads.Subject: DA14531: keep BOOST while CPU sleeping
Threads.Body:
The project runs form 1.5V battery on DA14531 in boost mode. The sensor connected to MCU requires 2.7V for 2 seconds and consumes 400 uA. It gets his power from P0_4 of DA14531.

Now I need to keep MCU running for 2 seconds to get 2.7V from the DCDC.

My question: Is it possible to run DCDC to get 2.7V while CPU is sleeping? I would like to save these few mA CPU is consuming.

Thank you!

Regards,
Rosty

I'm developing a BLE HID keyboard with few buttons. I started with BLE SDK6 example "HID-Gamepad-digitizer", removed joysticks and digitizer functionality, changed the report descriptor to report as a keyboard. It works on Android. I have mapped 4 buttons to type letters a,b,c,d.

Second question - when I use it with android, I need to pair again after BLE device power cycle. What I need to do to make the device reconnect automatically after power cycle?

- Hardware interrupt will come from Sensor gpio.

- then da14531 should wake up, Central will initiate the connection , after connection it will send data to mobile app , then central will disconnect.

- After disconnection event device will again go to sleep mode.

Regarding power consumption , tried enabling Extended sleep mode but it dint , work basically device should be oi sleep mode , When interrrupt comes it will wake up , Central will initialize the connection send the data and goes to sleep mode. This is Abishekh. I use the DA14695 USB DevKit. I am fairly new to RTOS. I tried running the gpio_handling_sample_code provided in the Github - BLE_SDK10_Examples. When I build the code and run it in Debugger, I do not face any Issues. Program using external  tools -> program_qspi_jtag (Using configurations as provided in getting started with DA1469x)

Unplug and Replug the USB-Kit.

When I run it via Debugger - I do not face any issues. Only happens when I program flash, unplug and replug device.

SDK Version:SDK_10.0.10.119.1 (I will Try updating this to latest version and will Update)

SmartSnippetsStudio: v2.0.20

Can someone clarify what is Happening here.

Regards,

Abishekh

Threads.Subject: DA14706 pro dev kit memory mapped psram
Threads.Body:
I am attempting to use the 8MB psram module (U2) on the devkit.  I have what I believe to be the correct configuration but when I do a simple memory test (write 8MB of values to 0x2800 0000 and then verify) at PSRAM[0x2000] it appears to overwrite PSRAM[0]...

Does this wring any bells? It is memory mapped right? :) 

I can read from a file system flashed to the 128MB flash by reading at 0x4800 0000 but psram has kicked my butt for two days.

Here is the applicable configuration (I think)

`

#define dg_configFLASH_ADAPTER (1)
#define dg_configNVMS_ADAPTER (0)
#define dg_configNVMS_VES (0)

#define dg_configFLASH_AUTODETECT (1)
#define dg_configQSPIC2_DEV_AUTODETECT (1)
#define dg_configFLASH_POWER_DOWN (1)

#define dg_configUSE_HW_QSPI (1)
#define dg_configUSE_HW_QSPI2 (1)
#define dg_configUSE_HW_DCACHE (1) `

And my test:

`

void psram_test()
{
uint32_t* PSRAM_BASE = ((uint32_t*)0x28000000);

bool match = true;

srand(0xB00B5);

printf("starting ram test:\n\rwriting");

for(int i = 0; i < 2 * 1024 * 1024; i++)
{
// if(!(i%1024)) printf("%i\n\r", i);

PSRAM_BASE[i] = rand();

//the line about starts overwriting at i== 0x800 

}
printf("\n\rverifying\n\r");

srand(0xB00B5);

for(int i = 0; i < 2 * 1024 * 1024; i++)
{
// if(!(i%1024)) printf("%i\n\r", i);

if( PSRAM_BASE[i] != rand())
{
match = false;
break;
}
}
printf("PSRAM memory test %s\n\r", match ? "passed" : "failed");
}

`

Threads.Subject: Understanding multi-bonding and differentiation of RPA devices in SDK 6.0.20 ble_app_security for DA14531MOD
Threads.Body:
Hello Forum.

Perusing the Renesas forum and the standard callback functions in SDK 6.0.20, I have a hard time figuring out if the RPA setup generates unique IRK's for the devices.
I found this post:
community.renesas.com/.../random-irk-generation-functions-for-pairing-devices
My impression is that there's no IRK generating function that generates a unique but static IRK. I would like to figure out if this is a problem for my use case.

Use case:
If I upload my firmware to multiple devices and try to bond to them on the same central, will there be problems differentiating the devices and achieve simultaneous connection to several of them?

My primary concern is differentiation between the devices and maintaining bonding between devices.

Any done implementations?
Maybe there's already written code I can implement somewhere, or maybe I need to figure out something myself.

Possible concept:
I imagine some implementation pulling a chip unique number from OTP to generate addresses and keys would be the best implementation and allow for static addresses and keys that remain the same after a power cycle to maintain bonding, while being unique between devices even though the firmware is identical.
Threads.EditNotes:
Too many spelling errors, made Bing clean it up and checked the information were intact
[edited by: Clk Victim at 16:41 (GMT 0) on 23 Nov 2023]

My impression is that there's no IRK generating function that generates a unique but static IRK. I would like to figure out if this is a problem for my use case.

Use case:
If I upload my firmware to multiple devices and try to bond to them on the same central, will there be problems differentiating the devices and achieve simultaneous connection to several of them?

My primary concern is differentiation between the devices and maintaining bonding between devices.

Any done implementations?
Maybe there's already written code I can implement somewhere, or maybe I need to figure out something myself.

Possible concept:
I imagine some implementation pulling a chip unique number from OTP to generate addresses and keys would be the best implementation and allow for static addresses and keys that remain the same after a power cycle to maintain bonding, while being unique between devices even though the firmware is identical.

Threads.Subject: Wakeup Dead batteries via DA14681
Threads.Body:
HI dialog

We are working on two custom boards based on DA14681. One has external charging ic "MP26029" and other is using DA14681's internal charging setup.

The problem which we are facing is that when customer dont use the device for a long time, battery's voltage drop too much. sometime it goes to 0.8V or 0.6V.

Then when we plug in the charger, DA14681's charger is not able to charge the battery, even after 24 hours of plug in the charger, but other board that has external charging IC, that charges the battery within 4 5 hours.

Please find the attached pdf of the charging settings.

Threads.Subject: When using a DA14683 how do you set it to work with a non USB charger
Threads.Body: We are suing the DA14683 with a standard wall wart charger that is not USB. Using the SDK we cannot get the charge current to be more than 90mA. How do we overcome this. I assume we cannot use the standard SDK for the battery charging, but cannot find anywhere which register to set to indicate a n non-USB charger. Any help gratefully received.

Threads.Subject: RESOLVE BD ADDRESS IN DA14531
Threads.Body:
Hi Sir,

            I am using the DA14531 Development Board. I have set the privacy address as APP_CFG_CNTL_PRIV_RPA_RAND. Now I want to resolve the BD address of my peripheral device. So, I want to call app_easy_security_resolve_bdaddr to send the stored IRK to the BLE stack and resolve the real BD address. However, in my central code, the callback function default_app_on_encrypt_req_ind is never called, and it doesn’t enter the function. What could be the reason?

Content.HtmlName: RESOLVE BD ADDRESS IN DA14531
Content.HtmlDescription:
Hi Sir,

            I am using the DA14531 Development Board. I have set the privacy address as APP_CFG_CNTL_PRIV_RPA_RAND. Now I want to resolve the BD address of my peripheral device. So, I want to call app_easy_security_resolve_bdaddr to send the stored IRK to the BLE stack and resolve the real BD address. However, in my central code, the callback function default_app_on_encrypt_req_ind is never called, and it doesn’t enter the function. What could be the reason?

Threads.Subject: Help implementing interrupt button press for indication in ble_app_security example for SDK 6.0.20
Threads.Body:
Hello OV and Forum
I have been looking into implementing a simple button press inside the ble_app_security example and have been looking at the simple_button and ble_Notify_button_Wakeup for reference.
I am confused as the folder structure, main structure and SDK implementation, in general, is different between the examples.

These examples also implements a lot of unwanted functionality like sleep and wakeup. My device should never sleep, nor do anything else than indicating a button press over secure ble.
I want to use the GATT implementaion in the security example using the "BUTTON_STATE" characteristic to communicate the button press. 

Are there any tutorial resource for a simple irq button press, updating the value and initiating an indication with the dentral?:

I suspect the implementation to go as follows:
1. gpio interrupt on a pin (pin 11) being pulled to ground

2. updating the characteristic

3. initiate an ble indication for the central to see new button value.

4. Reset button state when the peripheral recieves an Ack from the indication.

It seems to me that i'm out in mixing and matching examples but inexperience and different sdk structures are hindering me.

Content.HtmlName: Help implementing interrupt button press for indication in ble_app_security example for SDK 6.0.20
Content.HtmlDescription:
Hello OV and Forum
I have been looking into implementing a simple button press inside the ble_app_security example and have been looking at the simple_button and ble_Notify_button_Wakeup for reference.
I am confused as the folder structure, main structure and SDK implementation, in general, is different between the examples.

These examples also implements a lot of unwanted functionality like sleep and wakeup. My device should never sleep, nor do anything else than indicating a button press over secure ble.
I want to use the GATT implementaion in the security example using the "BUTTON_STATE" characteristic to communicate the button press. 

Are there any tutorial resource for a simple irq button press, updating the value and initiating an indication with the dentral?:

I suspect the implementation to go as follows:
1. gpio interrupt on a pin (pin 11) being pulled to ground

2. updating the characteristic

3. initiate an ble indication for the central to see new button value.

4. Reset button state when the peripheral recieves an Ack from the indication.

It seems to me that i'm out in mixing and matching examples but inexperience and different sdk structures are hindering me.

Hi ,

I am working Da14531 by interfacing pressure sensor over I2C, Observations

- If disconnect , then device wont advertise please suggest. attached code and screen shot for your reference.

assert_warning ERROR ITS SHOWING. 

Thanks in advance

PSk

Threads.Subject: DA14531 MOD ADC READ APP
Threads.Body:
Hello!
I have been reading the documentation about "custom profile" "LightBlue® application", working on the "ble_app_peripherial" project. Additionally I have been testing Timers and the ADC in another project.
I understand that in "LightBlue®" they do a test reading the status sent from the app to the server to turn on the LED, however I want to Read an ADC data from the app sent by the server... In the "ble_app_peripherial" they also have an ADC template, but I'm trying to understand in which part to put my function?
In this function I can think to put my ADC code, however it has the abbreviation cfg as configuration, but not read or write:
case SVC1_IDX_ADC_VAL_1_NTF_CFG:
user_svc1_adc_val_1_cfg_ind_handler(msgid, msg_param, dest_id, src_id);
break;
USER_CUTS1_IMPL.C:
void user_svc1_adc_val_1_cfg_ind_handler(ke_msg_id_t const msgid,
struct custs1_val_write_ind const *param,
ke_task_id_t const dest_id,
ke_task_id_t const src_id)
{
}

or Maybe in the ntf function ?:
struct custs1_val_ntf_cfm const *msg_param = (struct custs1_val_ntf_cfm const *)(param);

Doing the analogy for the led example you have the functional firmware code here, however you have the specific wr function, in this case I want to directly read the value in the app:
void user_svc1_led_wr_ind_handler(ke_msg_id_t const msgid,
struct custs1_val_write_ind const *param,
ke_task_id_t const dest_id,
ke_task_id_t const src_id)
{
uint8_t val = 0;
memcpy(&val, &param->value[0], param->length);

if (val == CUSTS1_LED_ON)
{
GPIO_SetActive(GPIO_LED_PORT, GPIO_LED_PIN);
}
else if (val == CUSTS1_LED_OFF)
{
GPIO_SetInactive(GPIO_LED_PORT, GPIO_LED_PIN);
}
}

This is my test code and I would like some guidance on where to put it, taking advantage of the template you provide, the app, and the ADC1 service:
result_bat = gpadc_read(); //WATCH SCALAR OR ATTENUATE AND ACHIEVE DISPLAY VALUE //SOLIDATE DIVIDER.
value_mv=gpadc_sample_to_mv(result_bat);
vdc=((float)value_mv/1000); // tests if increasing oversampling detects precision changes? //0.189 OFFSET
overs=adc_get_oversampling();

Thank you very much...

Threads.Subject: Adding custom services to the DA14531 DSPS source code
Threads.Body:
Greetings Everyone!

I recently started working with the Renesas DA14531 Bluetooth Low Energy. The application I have in mind will make use of the BLE module as a serial emulator (With a layer of Security). I have tested the SPS .hex file with an app and the BLE module is indeed acting as a serial emulator. As per the documentation for SPS in Renesas website (https://www.renesas.com/us/en/document/mat/um-b-088-da145x-user-manual-dialog-serial-port-service?r=1600786) the device application has the following service and characteristics which allows the data to be exchanged from BLE <==> UART:

SPS
SPS_SERVER_TX

SPS_SERVER_RX

SPS_FLOW_CTRL

These services/characteristics are not enough for my application and I would like to add more services that follow SPS to the example project and test it. Can you please help me with the documentation, if there is any? Any help is appreciated.

Best,

Vishnu

Threads.Subject: General questions about Wi-SUN (R9A06G062GNP)
Threads.Body:
Hello Team,

Sorry for post this thread under BLE I did not find Wi-SUN sub-group.

My customer has plan to use Wi-SUN as a low latency RF star network solution up to 100 end nodes.

Could you please advise back on the inquiries below:

1. What is the expected latency in an application of 100 end points and one border router? (the payload is 5 bytes).
2.What about collisions? should I manage the transmissions and acknowledges , or the Wi-Sun network deals with it?
3. Do you have a low latency application note?
4. What do you think about multiple networks in order to reduce the latency?

Waiting for your kind response, thanks in advance.

Regards,

Shai

Threads.Subject: DA14531 Secondary Bootloader + STM32
Threads.Body:
Hi all,

We have a custom PCB with a DA1531 and a STM32G473RCT6 and we are trying to implement firmware updates through UART between the MCU and the BLE module. Our currently UART connection it's made using P05 for RX and P06 for TX.

We are trying to use the secondary bootloader from the Mikroe BLE Tiny Click (secondary_bootloader_TxP06_RxP05_For_TinyClick_V101) since it uses the same UART pins. On the STM32 side we are following the steps described here (Booting the DA14531 with Codeless through a STM32).

The secondary bootloader initially works, it sends the STX (0x02) byte, but it keeps like this forever, even with the STM32 sending the SOH(0x01) and LEN_LSB/LEN_MSB. ACK is never sent.

Is there a better approach for this situation? 

Thanks in advance.

Content.HtmlDescription:

We have a custom PCB with a DA1531 and a STM32G473RCT6 and we are trying to implement firmware updates through UART between the MCU and the BLE module. Our currently UART connection it's made using P05 for RX and P06 for TX.

We are trying to use the secondary bootloader from the Mikroe BLE Tiny Click (secondary_bootloader_TxP06_RxP05_For_TinyClick_V101) since it uses the same UART pins. On the STM32 side we are following the steps described here (Booting the DA14531 with Codeless through a STM32).

The secondary bootloader initially works, it sends the STX (0x02) byte, but it keeps like this forever, even with the STM32 sending the SOH(0x01) and LEN_LSB/LEN_MSB. ACK is never sent.

Is there a better approach for this situation? 

Thanks in advance.

Threads.Subject: DA14531_01 can't power up with a short time power down when it's in hibernation mode
Threads.Body:
Hi Renesas engineer,


SDK ：6.0.20.1338

PCB： just like ‘da14531-ed-qfn-buck-376-33-a’

Code:

arch_set_hibernation(0, PD_SYS_DOWN_RAM_OFF, PD_SYS_DOWN_RAM_OFF, PD_SYS_DOWN_RAM_OFF, 0,false);


Appearance:

1） When the above code run, the power cost is 0.3uA (measured by a multimeter)
2） disconnect power 3s， it's 0uA
3）power again， it's 0.3uA again， And the system can't run. It seems like it's still in sleep mode.

if disconnect power time > 15s, power again the system is normal.

Please confirm the problem and give me a suggestion.

(My plan is set product to hibernation mode in final factory test. And the customer resetting cell battery before use.)

Threads.Subject: DA14531 BER and advertisement modes
Threads.Body:
Hi everyone,

I have a few questions regarding BLE DA14531:


1. if there's an existing mechanism to put our BLE chip in test mode where we can do a loop back test to determine the BER?

2.Is there a fast advertising mode and a slow advertising mode in the SDK, and if so, how do you configure them?

Thanks.

Hi everyone,

Threads.Subject: Pairing and Bonding with numeric comparison in DA14531
Threads.Body:
Hello Sir,

      I have implemented numeric comparison method based pairing in DA14531 in the central role.

      When I try to pair and bond with mobile acting as the peripheral ( which BT address is changing frequently), I can able bond the device. It didn't asking for pairing again and again.

      When I try the same with the BLE_SECURITY_EXAMPLE ( which has the private random resolvable address) , It asks the for pairing again and again.

      Here I am checking the bond table based on the BD address not using IRK and still it can able detect the mobile's random address

      Why the DA14531 (acting as the central ) can able to detect the mobile's random address but not the BLE_SECURITY_EXAMPLE.

      For your reference.

      pbd = app_easy_security_bdb_search_entry(SEARCH_BY_BDA_TYPE, (void *)app_env[conidx].peer_addr.addr, BD_ADDR_LEN);

Threads.Subject: Random Resolvable Private Address with MITM PASSKEY or with static OOB code sticker in SDK 6.0.20
Threads.Body:
Hello BLE Forum. I have been poking around the security tutorial for DA145xx compatible with SDK 6.0.20:
https://lpccs-docs.renesas.com/Tutorial-DA145x-BLE-Security

I am trying to achieve one of two things:

  1. Bonded RPA with IRK and encryption established on top of Association using passkeys (where i hard code a passkey into the firmware)
  2. Bonded RPA with IRK and encryption established using OOB which essentially is a known passkey manually input by the user.

Trying the first option, essentially mixing and matching the two examples in the tutorial, I end up with a setup that requests a passkey when i connect over bluetooth, but the connection never succeeds even as i enter my user defined passkey. having it on for 15 minutes does, however, make the DA14531 advertise a new BLA Address.

I have tried using bare android and using the light blue app.

I see the second option as a plan b and haven't attempted it yet.

Have anyone tried anything similar?

The Device
The final device has no screen and only one button but i plan on putting a sticker on it containing the passcode unique to the device.

What is needed from me to help me?
As it is all done in the example based off of the tutorial, I am not shy of sharing everything in the current state as it contains no custom code.community.renesas.com/.../ble_5F00_app_5F00_security.zip

I admit to having a vague understanding of the BL security features intercompatibility so ignorance should generally be assumed on my part.

Threads.Subject: DA14531 - Flashing
Threads.Body:
Hello Sir,

       We have designed our custom board using DA14531 bluetooth module. Initially when we try to flash and debug the chip it was working perfectly fine. 

       We try to update the software after few months,chip itself not detected in Smartbond flash programmer. We have faced the same issue with 50% of our custom boards.

       Kindly provide solution to solve this issue.

Thanks and regards.
